newsitem.title: SPAIN: Argentaria H1 dips, sees full-yr turnaround.
newsitem.headline: Argentaria H1 dips, sees full-yr turnaround.

text.p: Spain's Argentaria posted on Monday a 10.7 percent earnings drop in the first half of 1997, but said staff cutbacks would help boost full-year profit growth by more than 10 percent.
The net attributable income of Spain's third-largest bank declined to 33.24 billion pesetas ($214 million) from 37.22 billion pesetas.
"Net attributable profit is going to grow by more than two digits (for the full year)," Chairman Francisco Gonzalez told a news conference.
Argentaria, which is still 29.2 percent state-owned, has aggressively restructured to cut costs, boost profitability and offset the drawbacks of having a relatively small domestic branch network.
Net interest income -- which reflects earnings on loans after costs from deposits -- rose to 108.51 billion pesetas from 97.37 billion.
Ordinary income, which also includes fees and commissions and trading income, climbed to 151.06 billion pesetas from 140.06 billion.
As a result and in the light of moderate growth in costs, operating revenue, a traditional yardstick of basic banking, rose a solid 12.6 percent.
"The results that we are presenting are very good. We have put tremendous importance on recurring income," Gonzalez said. "This is an enormous qualitative change."

But perhaps even more important is the deal, announced on Friday, to slim down its Banco Exterior (BEX) unit, which has been hampered by above-average wage costs and has been considered the group's Achilles' Heel.
Argentaria, which was formed in 1991 through the merger of six state-owned banks and savings bank, agreed with unions to cut 2,100 jobs at BEX over the coming three years.
The entire Banco Exterior de Espana group, which includes national and foreign units, currently has 8,218 workers on its payroll.
"This deal puts an end to the bank's two principal problems of the last two years -- too many people and an inapproprate union agreement," said BEX Managing Director Federico Outon.
Despite a sharp improvement at home, the bank is not yet ready to extend its reach abroad, although Gonzalez reiterated the group's interest in Latin America.

While Argentaria has been tidying up on the home front, Spain's top two banks, Santander and Banco Bilbao Vizcaya have sunk a combined $5.3 billion pesetas into the region this decade, spending $2.1 billion this year alone.
"This group has more aspirations and we think Latin America is a good opportunity, but there are priorities," Gonzalez said.
Argentaria, which has said it has almost 300 billion pesetas available for purchases, is active in fund management in Bolivia, but has only minimal presence in the region.
"We want to be (there) when an opportunity surfaces, not when the others do it," Gonzalez said.
